rules_detail.title: How to Solve Nonograms
rules_detail.intro: Nonograms (Japanese crosswords) are logic puzzles in which you need to fill cells in accordance with numbers indicated on the left of rows and at the top of columns.
rules_detail.h1_p: Each number shows how many **consecutive** filled cells are in this row or column.
rules_detail.h1_li1: If there is a number 5 in a row, it means there is a block of five filled cells in it.
rules_detail.h1_li2: If there are several numbers, for example 3 1, this means that in this row there is first a block of three cells, and then ‚Äî a block of one.
rules_detail.h1_li3: Important: There must be at least one empty (unfilled) cell between two blocks of filled cells.
rules_detail.h2_p: Look for rows or columns that can be filled immediately. For example, if the grid size is 10x10 and there is a 10 in a row ‚Äî then the entire row will be filled.
rules_detail.h3_p: If you are sure that a cell should be empty, place a cross (RMB) in it. This will help you cut off impossible options and find the correct solution faster.
rules_detail.example_p: Example for hint 3 1: three cells are filled, one is empty (cross), one is filled.
rules_detail.h4_li3: Hold and drag: You can fill several cells in a row at once.
